ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about single-variable calculus, covering chain rule, differentiation, trig identities, L'Hopital's Rule, fundamental theorem of calculus, antiderivatives, differential equations, etc. We had weekly problem sets and workshops with ULAs where we went over harder problems. There are a lot of ULA and professor office hours so lots of support.
I learned calculus, and how to use it. CJ taught it in a very fun way that made going to class a treat.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: This course covers all topics in single-variable calculus, with lots of support and review from ULAs and professors. 

Weaknesses: Problem Set Questions can sometimes be overcomplicated. Lots of application questions that can be difficult to understand.

I think this course was taught well in class but the homework problems from the book were always either something completely different from what we learned in class or just severely complicated and in order to do well in the class I had to spend around 5 hours per week in office hours to complete the problem sets despite knowing what was going on in class. I think the problem sets were very frustrating and not at all helpful to the course as they did not reflect the style questions we saw in class and on tests.
After resubmitting a concept check for the 3rd time, I think more guidance should be given. At that point its pretty clear theres something Im not grasping but were not allowed to receive help.

Weakness: its math, so naturally it can get confusing and dull

Strengths: C.J. is an amazing professor who did his best to make class exciting and understandable. He works hard to ensure his students take the most from the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I recommend this course to a student who isn't very strong in math or who hasn't taken a calculus class. I liked being able to learn basic calculus over the course of a year instead of a semester and found the extra attention from professors and ULAs very helpful. I often went to ULA office hours to ask questions about problem sets and they did a good job explaining and walking through problems.
Yes because the professors were very helpful throughout the year and explained the concepts very well.
Yes, it is a fun and simple math credit, and teaches the basics.
